ygData.subject: Re: Is AHNI the only java hyperneat implementation?

Thanks Oliver! I'll try to enhance AHNI by modifying it to read i/o from fi=
les.

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Oliver Coleman <oliver.coleman@...> wrot=
e:
>
> Hi Ron,
> 
> I'm the author of AHNI. As far as I know AHNI is the on=
ly Java
> implementation of HyperNEAT. Experiments typically use parameters=
 given in
> a .properties file (which is given as an argument when running =
AHNI). It
> would be easy to write a fitness function class that reads inpu=
t and output
> examples from files specified in the properties file. See
> =
com.anji.objectrecognition. ObjectRecognitionFitnessFunction3.java for an
>=
 example to get started.
> 
> I'm currently writing a new version of AHNI t=
hat will implement extensions
> such as ES-HyperNEAT, allow using the Bain =
neural network simulator (
> https://github.com/OliverColeman/bain ), and w=
ill be refactored to make the
> code a bit neater. It's on github but may n=
ot be stable or working just yet.
> 
> Cheers,
> Oliver
> On Sep 30, 2012 4=
:44 AM, "roncking2001" <roncking@...> wrote:
> 
> > **
> >
> >
> > Hi All,
=
> >
> > I want a java version of hyperneat. AHNI appears to have to example=
s that
> > are 'hard coded' in java classes, and I want something that can =
do new
> > experiments where the input and output come from files instead. =
I'm
> > especially wanting to do more vision experiments.
> >
> > Is there =
any other implementations out there?
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > Ron
> >
> >  =

> >
>
